title: Is it more advantageous to file Bankruptcy before a settlement is reached or after?
question: I was going to file Chapter 7 but was struck by a crazy driver which caused injuries. Her insurance took full responsibility for it as she was 100% at fault. I have high medical bills so expecting a large settlement but it's probably months away.
answers:
You must see an experienced attorney for many reasons. For example what if an attorney says you can exempt so much under CA law and then you learn NO..you cannot because you did not live in CA more than 2 years before you filed? If that happened to you you can understand why it is not just simple. OTher facts and issues can affect your case.

Some persons, if they would lose most of a settlement, might settle, take the money, by a small home, etc. or put in places to try and maximize exemptions before the file at some point in the future. Thus find a CA attorney now..there are great ones on here.

You need and want to enjoy your fresh start also. But the most important thing is to meet with an attorney as you asking this question means you have not. You care about 2 goals: keeping everything you have equity in and discharging all your debts. If you don't have any of the exceptions to discharge you will obtain that goal; most exceptions are set forth in 11 USC. 523 (Google it) like child support, some income taxes, traffic (in a ch 7) and criminal fines , and presumption of student loans. But some debts are dischargeable in a ch 13 but NOT in a ch 7 so you want to make sure and your attorney will discuss any such types with you also!

Your exemptions depend on what state you have lived in in the last 2 years and thus if in your state, then your states exemptions will apply. Most persons filing keep everything they own but your attorney will confirm that with you when they learn everything you own and the equity thereof!

Some secured debts like homes, vehicles, other secured debts an attorney will discuss your options on also as you must list any debts; but that does not mean you will lose them unless you have too much equity or are in default on paying for them! Discuss those options if they apply with your attorney too.

But other issues can arise that can greatly harm your case. Just one example: If you paid back a relative $3,000 11 months ago and now file bankruptcy next week, the trustee can SUE that relative to retrieve that $3,000 (under what is called a preference) for the benefit of the bankruptcy estate. As a result, most attorneys don't charge to meet with them the first meeting so meet with one no matter what.

Many great attorneys can be found right here on AVVO in your state so look, call, and meet one as soon as you can.

You should also want to know when to file: is there an advantage of waiting versus filing now and who should you pay between now and then! Good luck and enjoy your later fresh start.

You really NEED to speak with an experienced bankruptcy attorney. If you file prior to settling the PI case, the trustee could assume control of that claim and use all the settlement to benefit your creditors and you might not see a penny. Of course, this depends on what California law allows to be exempted and an experienced California attorney can discuss that with you.
Without knowing substantially more information, is impossible to know. Talk to an experienced bankruptcy attorney to determine your options.

More facts are needed to give you useful advice. You need the "back and forth" with a competent BK lawyer as one question leads to another, etc. BK is not a DIY project consisting of checking boxes on forms you find on-line. Find/consult/hire an Avvo BK lawyer by using the "Find a Lawyer" feature. Make a list consisting of several BK lawyers having many 5 star reviews from satisfied clients. If you don't get a prompt call back, go on to the next one on your list. Some of us offer a free consultation by phone or in person. Take us up on it. If this answer was helpful, please leave your feedback on the Avvo website as “best answer or helpful”. Good luck to you.
